instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  Not Turning On
threads.message:
I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board not powering up, F4800 got got 12v on both sides, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 0V , whats next?

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12v on battery but 0v when using USB C adaptor (ggod adaptor)

No history of liquid damage

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  Not Turning On
threads.message:
Any history available?
You must work on the board without battery, untill get correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with charger only.

Probably one <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip is bad.
Must check some voltages and diode mode readings on the their power pins...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  Not Turning On
threads.message: Never measure with the battery attached it will not help you. Do you have 5 volts or 20 volts on DC-in with just the charger?

threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 54398"]Never measure with the battery attached it will not help you. Do you have 5 volts or 20 volts on DC-in with just the charger?[/QUOTE]

Actually when started working on it, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is fine using the charger but yesterday it went kaput

threads.message:

Do you get 5V or 20V at USB-C input port?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  Not Turning On
threads.message: My apologies, actually i don't know where to start, these USB power issues are pain in the butt, ok ill check power pins of <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  Not Turning On
threads.message:
<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>

Pin 2 <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 1.8v
Pin 10 <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 5v
Pin 11 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 0v
Pin 12 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
Pin 35 <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0v
Pin 70 <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL> = 5v
Pin 75 <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0v

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>

Pin 2 <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0v (still 0v even when i change the charger usb port)
Pin 10 <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 5v
Pin 11 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 0v
Pin 12 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 2.3v
Pin 35 <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0v
Pin 70 <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL> = 0v (got 5v when i change the charger usb port)
Pin 75 <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  Not Turning On
threads.message: PPDCIN is 5 volts so forget any voltage from PPBUS on for the moment. DCIN must be 20 volts. Post voltage for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  Not Turning On
threads.message:
"<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
-------------------------
Pin 2 <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0v (still 0v even when i change the charger usb port)
---------------
Pin 12 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 2.3v"
You just found the culprit.
Comparing diode mode readings between chips can help too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  Not Turning On
threads.message: Changed <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> now boots, damn you guys are good!
